#Text=South American leaders end border dispute
#Text=Saturday , March 8 , 2008

#Text=An exchange of handshakes at a Latin American summit Friday marked the end of the bitter dispute that had taken place between the nations of Colombia , Ecuador , and Venezuela over the past week .
#Text=The presidents of each country agreed to end the conflict , and said political ties would be reinstated .

#Text=" With the commitment of never attacking a brother country again and by asking forgiveness , we can consider this very serious incident resolved , " said Ecuadorian president Rafael Correa , as the other Latin American leaders applauded .

column1: #Text=The Rio Group summit , which included 20 Latin American nations , was originally planned to discuss other issues such as energy , but it soon erupted into a series of verbal attacks between Correa and Colombian president Álvaro Uribe .
#Text=The dispute was over Colombia 's air strike against FARC rebels , which Ecuador accused of entering their territory .
#Text=As a result , Ecuador and their ally Venezuela had sent troops to their borders and severed ties with Colombia .
#Text=At the summit , Uribe charged Correa 's government of having links with the FARC rebels , a charge that Correa quickly denied .
#Text=" I cannot accept Uribe 's lies , " he said .
#Text=" These hands are not tainted with blood . "
#Text=He admitted there had been communication with the FARC , but only regarding the release of hostages held by the rebels , including French-Colombian politician Íngrid Betancourt .
#Text=Uribe insisted that Ecuador has not done enough to fight the rebels , which was the reason the operation had to remain a secret , he said .
#Text=" We have not gotten cooperation from President Correa in the fight against terrorism . "
#Text=Correa then advocated the creation of an international peacekeeping force to control the border , saying that Ecuador has become a victim of the fighting in Colombia .
#Text=Venezuelan president Hugo Chávez , who was initially a central figure in the conflict , urged the leaders to stay calm .
#Text=" We still have time to stop a whirlpool which we could regret , " he said .
#Text=" Let 's reflect , let 's be cool-headed . "
#Text=He also denied claims that he had supplied FARC with $ 300 million and offered to give them rifles .
#Text=" I could have sent a lot of rifles to the FARC , " Chávez said .
#Text=" I will never do it because I want peace . "
#Text=Finally , it was Dominican president Leonel Fernandez plea for peace that ended the feud .
#Text=He requested that the presidents shake hands with each other , which they did , in a televised gesture viewed live across Latin America .
#Text=Nicaragua 's president , Daniel Ortega , also agreed to reinstate diplomatic ties with Colombia after shaking hands with their president .
#Text=The leaders at the summit later approved a declaration in which Uribe apologized for the military operation and vowed never again to violate another nation 's sovereignty .
#Text=It also mentioned a commitment to fight against threats posed by " irregular or criminal groups . "
